page.title: 02Hundleby Village.
page.content: Hundleby is a very ancient village; it's Nordic name suggests that it was started in the ninth century a.d. Hundleby is situated on the ridge way of the Wolds and the north facing bank of the river Lymn which was probably used as the water supply. The buildings in the village are varied in style as the old have been pulled down to make way for the new. There is now only one mud and stud building with a thatched roof left althouth there is no doubt that there were many others. In the eighteenth century, a brick pit was opened and many of the buildings in the village were rebuilt using home made bricks. There are forty eight houses with pantile roofs. The tiles were probably imported from Holland as ballast for otherwise empty returning ships.
